threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

3. Switch (ew @ having to be connected)

>>9466703
In general you don't want a consumer TV that will do 480p. Those were EDTVs. They're not all that common and they used digital processing which means input lag. I have a 14' Advent brand set I got from Goodwill with component and S-video. It doesn't do 480p, but I'm glad it doesn't, that's a good thing. Monitors are a different story. If you need a CRT to do 480p that's the direction you want to look, but outside of PVMs you're not too likely to find the specific inputs you want.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9462864
>I always noticed how much he generally hated gaming and viewed it as a big waste of time
You're probably right on this one. John Carmack basically said the same thing, and he would have had a front row seat into dealing with Jobs. Apparently Jobs thought of video games as "pornos" where "the plot didn't matter". To him, Pixar was the bastion of digital creativity, games were for peasants. When they released Doom, Carmack wanted to include "produced on NeXT" branding, but Jobs denied the request. Years later, Jobs would do everything in his power to prevent OSX from being a more game-friendly platform. I think Carmack said something along the lines of how Jobs "could talk, with complete confidence, about things he was just plain wrong about".

The man had some good ideas but it's a real shame that he was such a dick about this particular thing. People used to joke that "Mac = PS3 = noegaems" but the 90s were good for Mac gaming considering that the platform was in complete collapse. It's why I keep a few old ugly duckling beige Macs around, whereas I've basically purged my house of any Mac made between 2000 and 2020. There is something alluring about the Classic Mac OS, but there is nothing that would tie me to old versions of OS X.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Sega were an arcade company so they did know how to build things well and solidly and they worked with Hitachi who had a top-tier chip fab and engineers. However it may also be the case that Sega consoles tended to be trimmed down arcade boards so most of the technology in them was already proven and tested. Nintendo are not necessarily as good, although the DMG Gameboy was as indestructible as it got. in the cartridge era they also worked with Ricoh who were ok but not as good as Hitachi. N64 onward are very solid but those used proven SGI, IBM and other such chipsets. I mean they bought a preexisting SGI chipset for the N64, it wasn't a bespoke design. Sony consoles have had lots of issues probably due to their emphasis on volume uber alles. They build consoles in ginormous quantities so some shortcuts and penny pinching inevitably happen.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9467092
You can make things trigger infinitely pretty easily enough if you wanted to make it a kind of 'horde mode' against the heroes. Here's a simple script that keeps spawning archers every 600 turns:

SET_TIMER(PLAYER0,TIMER0)

IF(PLAYER0,TIMER0 >= 1000)

NEXT_COMMAND_REUSABLE
ADD_CREATURE_TO_LEVEL(PLAYER_GOOD,ARCHER,-3,1,6,600)

NEXT_COMMAND_REUSABLE
SET_TIMER(PLAYER0,TIMER0)

ENDIF


The challenge I guess is making it in such a way that it doesn't get too repetitive and boring. The first thing to consider is to have a 'tier' system so that the player is attacked by progressively harder heroes (and use flags to t

I would mix in specific game conditions like TOTAL_CREATURES and TOTAL_GOLD_MINED and so on as ways to move to the next tier of enemies in a way that isn't immediately obvious to the player (if it's all solely on timers then players will figure out how to game it quicker).

To add variety and replay-ability to the game I'd build the hero parties dynamically in the script. So in your CREATE_PARTY and add different heroes/creatures depending on conditions. In the original game, random was limited. I used a very short timer that is resetting often, say every 8 turns but I see KeeperFX makes it pretty easy to add variety with its DRAWFROM command without having to waste a timer.

For example, lets say we're at tier 1. In your CREATE_PARTY your 'thugs' party could be picking out heroes from a set list of early campaign levels (like thief). Diggers could be from the two variety of tunnellers and so on, and keeping the levels low.

Then in a repeating timer (like the earlier script), you could add:

ADD_PARTY_TO_LEVEL(PLAYER0,DRAWFROM(thugs,diggers),DRAWFROM(-6,-9),1)

This will spawn either thugs or diggers party at hero gate 6 or 9. You could then have a separate repeating timer which is altering the thugs party and checking what the current difficulty is and maybe deciding to pick knights instead of thieves and so on.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9467738
>(and use flags to t
to track progress through tiers).

Regarding pacing, some little tricks I used over the years was if you're already at the point where you're stepping up the difficulty (say half way through your sequence),

You might be at a timer that's going to spawn say three parties of heroes. I used to check:

if TOTAL_CREATURES_LEFT >= 10

Before spawning the third party to give the keeper more of a chance of fending off that wave. I found I got less complaints about difficulty when I added logic like that.

When you get to the very last part of your script, where you know it's just doing to be DRAWFROM variations, you can add logic which adds more of a challenge, e.g. an extra party to attack if they have >= 20 creatures to prevent them from getting too strong (so they can keep crushing waves comfortably). In the late game, made use of the ADD_TO_FLAG to keep make the loops to add heroes to the map a little longer each time, it's still worth putting in some hard cap on it in case there are too many things to draw on screen, in fact reaching such a caps a good reason to take the player to the final set of waves.

It's a bit cliche to put a 'boss' party that has the avatar and a bunch of heroes on repeat. Fighting the avatar takes forever even with strong creatures and will get boring to do over and over. Try to make your boss party a little more diverse if repeating it, maybe a witch or wizard leads the party sometimes. When deciding to repeat elements, I found it more enjoyable to group by spells, e.g. select some from a group that can heal, then some with hand to hand, and so on. For one of the groups I picked the same hero from a list of strong heroes at random, with some variation on group size and level which was amusing to watch people play and wonder how 6 level 10 Samurai got into their dungeon, running around fast using lightening spells to kill imps!

I always found people tended to overdo it with the final waves.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9467862
Pauses in the action are vital, so the player can try to recover and prepare for the next wave. A good example to study is level 11 in the campaign (Hearth). What you're aiming for is a war of attrition in that kind of style. Small parties attacking from multiple sides are better than just sending in a big wave (that's the kind of thing boulder traps were made for). Reducing the timer slightly is a nice way to increase pressure. Between every tier change (with stronger/increased heroes added to party) I'd always give plenty of breathing room, that way at least if they don't make it they can analyse what they did and think, 'yeah okay I should've trained my dragons for a while longer instead of leaving them on research, it would've meant I would've won that fight'.

Some logic to try to punish turtling, I always had a party or two that its job was just to harass the player in some form if they hadn't progressed (triggered an expected flag by a certain amount of time, given ample time, this timer would keep repeating until they got to the expected trigger).

Another thing to do is always to limit the amount of gold, players had to keep digging it out and things like gems were on further reaches of the maps (and a great place to put enemy keepers or hero gates in the way to force the player to eventually fight).

Also there's a mistake in my explanation here >>9467738 the 600 is starting gold for the creature if I remember, the script is actually every 1,000 turns (as per timer).

One idea for a multiplayer map I had was where there are keepers in the corners, gems in the middle but it's also got a lot of hero gates around them that spawn waves of heroes in the manner described. Heroes attack all keepers, so it might make sense to team up to fight them if their numbers get too great. But if one keeper is too strong maybe you don't want to help him, maybe you even lead heroes to his base. But if he goes, one less keeper messes with hero balance.

last_replies.com:
>>9467459
>I'm still not sure what this thing is
You're familiar with the term FPGA, in a loose fashion, yeah? MiSTer is a project that is taking advantage of a cheap FPGA that people can buy, called the DE-10 Nano. The DE-10 Nano is cheap because it is made for college students, and is subsidized by Intel. The DE-10 Nano has an FGPA on board, as well as an ARM chip. It has various connectors on the board for expandability. MiSTer has a bunch of FPGA cores (much like the cores you would see on one of the Analog systems) for consoles, handhelds, arcade boards and computers. Developers are constantly adding more cores and improving on existing cores. A hobbiest community has popped up around this project, which has led to a lot of hardware addons that can be installed onto the DE-10 Nano, such as extra RAM, a digital or analog I/O board, USB hub (these things make up the most common MiSTer setup that you have likely seen, which is a sandwich of three boards with the DE-10 Nano in the middle)... etc. There are people who have made specialized expansion boards like the MiSTercade, which allows it to be used in a typical JAMMA arcade cabinet. At a base level, you really just need the DE-10 Nano, and preferably a RAM stick, the rest is optional.

MiSTer can be appealing to enthusiasts because it offers better accuracy/latency compared to software emulation. It's also very easy to set up and use in a variety of scenarios, without having to invest in a bunch of extra shit like flash carts, upscalers, custom cables... etc. It is an all-in-one solution for many of the systems that a retro gamer would be interested in. By its nature, it is also very customizable.

I still think that software emulation is a good option, especially on a budget since you can probably do it on hardware that you already own, however I do like my MiSTer quite a bit and I find that I am playing more /vr/ games than ever since getting it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9467670
It could only display a few sprites on the same scanline, and slightly more all over the screen without severely impacting the performance. Graphic files were taken from the ROM cart and thus couldn't be modified on the go without an external chip and at least 4 times as much RAM as what the console came with. You couldn't render a huge sprite without stitching several small sprites together, and you couldn't have a sprite smaller than 8x8, which hurt the performance.

>>9467551
Morrowinds archetecture and art style and biomes are all amazing. I do play it with 105 mods for facelifts in textures, meshes, bodies, and ui improvements today but it was absolutely magical when I was 10 playing it on xbox with 10 minute load screens. I couldn't believe how an entire other world came to life with myths and mysteries populating every nook. Oblivion was a step down from this, sure, but it was still a fun romp and it was rushed. The biggest improvement between morrowind and oblivion that makes morrowind feel lifeless in retrospect is the static lives of npcs. People complained about the overhyped time cycle ai of oblivion but it really is a breath of life into the world. Oblivion at least maintained the leveling system of morrowind while making it casual. Skyrim is just horrific and unforgivable. It has zero creativity, no soul, no life, no atmosphere, and a horrific leveling system devoid of choice or thought. Oblivion has less soul in a serious sense than morrowind, but it has a dime novel fantasy feel that redeems this with a tongue in cheek schlock. Skyrim fails at everything entirely. It is neither seruous nor fun, exceptionally creative nor exceptionally polished. Witcher 3 is not very creative or groundbreaking but it is exceptionally polished. Skyrim is an irredeemable piece of shit. Oblivion has redeeming qualities.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9465260
You can beat the Japanese version on the hardest difficulty without a problem by spamming dash attacks smartly. Especially with Zan. Stay on the bottom of the screen and spam dash attacks (blitzes) with him. His upgraded blitzes normally have a dumb zigzag movement that is detrimental, but if you stay on the bottom of the screen, there's no more zigzag, and it becomes game-breaking (at least on the Japanese version). Or you can pick Blaze and spam her jump kick, but maneuver her in the air so that the very tip of her toe hits the enemy. That move pretty much nullifies anything in the game (Japanese version).

Earlier I said to use specials for the i-frames on the level 2 bosses (US version), but you should know that Blaze's forward special doesn't have any i-frames. Zan's forward special does. If you want an easy way to beat the Mona Lisa fight, pick Zan, and wait for Mona/Lisa/both to land from a jump and blast them with his forward special. It has amazing reach and i-frames so you will nullify anything they do. Just don't do it when they're doing their ground fireball attack because THEY have i-frames. If you just know when bosses have i-frames you can nullify everything else they do with Zan's forward special.

>That's the windows 9x port of Sega Touring car. It did come out in 1998 for the PC, it was one of the later Saturn to PC ports and probably has less issues. I had a copy of Sega Rally for Windows and ran it on Windows 98se in 1999-2000-ish. I played it with a Gravis Gamepad Pro, and the game is virtually identical to the Saturn game, when you are playing it in software mode. Though in software mode the default resolution is 320x240 and the game runs at 30fps. But it also has Direct3D mode for higher resolution graphics. I think Sega Rally supported 640x480 and 800x600 at 16bit colour mode, as well. It added filtering, texture correction, and a bit of fogging. But still ran at 30fps.

the Sega PC ports are what they are. Made to run on mid-level PC's sold at a discount price. The Win 95 port of Sega Rally 95 is identical to the Saturn game. I had the Saturn game, and the PC game. i was disappointed by the PC version looking just like the Saturn game. It did'nt look like the arcade, still runs at a locked 30fps. But supports D3D hardware acceleration.It was OK for this type of port.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=30P1a5bUghI&t=169s

The Windows XP port of Sega Rally 2 is interesting, because it was apparently developed before the Dreamcast game, and was ported to the Dreamcast using WindowsCE.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xsbm7YEbV-E&t=5s

The Windows XP port is better. Runs at a solid 60fps, has higher resolution settings. The Dreamcast port was gimped with a 30-60fps framerate.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9449094
on a technical level, i don't know and i don't care.

i guess i'll choose medium difficulty on this one. so mainly the reason i fuck with retro games at all is i'm looking for more games to play that i enjoy. it'll be hard to make this a short and snappy post, but let me try to summarize:

at the end of the day, fun as far as our brains are concerned has to do with a sweet spot of difficulty and skill. you can look into the psychology of flow if you want, but it's a lot of ideas/concepts/memes/hypotheticals/people trying to get your money. however, it's a real idea: if you find the sweet spot on the axis of challenge and your skill level, you're likely to have "fun". it varies for everyone, which is why some games will dynamically adjust the difficulty. dynamic difficulty should've been something developers worked on hard throughout the years, but either they had their own ideas of what constitutes an appropriately difficult game, or it's too hard, too pie in the sky to make a game with dynamic difficulty that actually works. although i doubt it because max payne and RE4 seem to do fine. this is why games like mario 3 have a lot of options, or "meaningful choices". don't want to do a stage? use a cloud. hell, use a whistle and skip the whole world. want to clear every level the old fashioned way without using any powerups from the toolbelt? you can do that too.

the point i'm making here is there's a lot more than hardware and software going on with games in general. i like games because they're toys for your brain. i'm not trying to impress anyone, and i don't need to have an idealized experience on trve hardware. if it works, it works. if it doesn't, it doesn't.
